description: Calculate the weighted average RMS median age difference score comparing the model Age-[O/Fe] relation to the APOGEE/L23 data for the Two-infall SFH combined with the Triple-system DTD.
instructions: 1. Extract and load the multi-zone VICE simulation output from `multizone.tar.gz`, specifically locating the model that combines the Two-infall Star Formation History (SFH) with the Triple-system Delay-Time Distribution (DTD) as described in \ref{sec:methods}.
2. Load the APOGEE data from `sample.csv` using appropriate data reading functions, ensuring all columns including stellar parameters, abundances, and Gaia EDR3 astrometric data are accessible.

3. Calculate galactocentric radius $R_{\text{gal}}$ and height above the midplane $z$ for each APOGEE star using the Gaia EDR3 data with the specified solar parameters: $R_{\odot} = 8.122$ kpc and $z_{\odot} = 20.8$ pc.
4. Apply the quality cuts specified in \ref{tab:quality_cuts}: $1.0 < \log g < 3.8$, $3500 < T_{\text{eff}} < 5500$ K, S/N $> 80$, ASPCAPFLAG bit 23 not set, EXTRATARG bits 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4 not set.
5. Merge the APOGEE data with the L23 age estimates, retaining only stars with L23 age uncertainty (`Age_sigma_L23`) $< 40\\%$ as recommended in \ref{sec:observational_sample}.
6. Apply additional spatial cuts: $3 < R_{\text{gal}} < 15$ kpc and $|z| < 2$ kpc to focus on the Galactic disk population.

7. For each model stellar population in the VICE simulation output, apply random Gaussian scatter to the [O/Fe] abundance using the median observational uncertainty of $0.019$ dex from \ref{tab:uncertainties}.
8. Apply random Gaussian scatter to the logarithmic age values $\log(\text{Age}/\text{Gyr})$ for model stellar populations using the median uncertainty of $0.10$ dex from \ref{tab:uncertainties}.
9. Convert logarithmic ages to linear ages in Gyr for both model stellar populations and APOGEE/L23 data: $\text{Age} = 10^{\log(\text{Age}/\text{Gyr})}$.
10. Divide both model and observational samples into the 18 Galactic regions defined by $R_{\text{gal}}$ bins (3-5, 5-7, 7-9, 9-11, 11-13, 13-15 kpc) and $|z|$ bins (0-0.5, 0.5-1.0, 1.0-2.0 kpc).
11. Within each of the 18 regions, create [O/Fe] bins with width $0.05$ dex covering the full range of observed [O/Fe] values.

12. For each [O/Fe] bin $k$ that contains stars from both the model and APOGEE/L23 samples, calculate the mass-weighted median age of model stars: $\text{med}(\tau_{\text{VICE}})$ and the median age of APOGEE/L23 stars: $\text{med}(\tau_{\text{L23}})$.
13. Compute the age difference for each bin: $\Delta\tau_k = \text{med}(\tau_{\text{VICE}}) - \text{med}(\tau_{\text{L23}})$.

14. Calculate the RMS median age difference for each region using \ref{eq:rms_age}: $\Delta\tau_{\text{RMS}} = \sqrt{\sum_k \frac{(\Delta\tau_k)^2 \cdot n_{\text{L23},k}}{n_{\text{L23,tot}}}}$, where $n_{\text{L23},k}$ is the number of APOGEE/L23 stars in bin $k$ and $n_{\text{L23,tot}}$ is the total number in the region.
15. Exclude [O/Fe] bins that contain no model stars or no observed stars from the RMS calculation to avoid undefined or biased results.

16. Compute the final score $S$ as the weighted average of $\Delta\tau_{\text{RMS}}$ values across all 18 regions: $S = \sum_{\text{regions}} \Delta\tau_{\text{RMS}} \cdot n_{\text{L23,tot}} / \sum_{\text{regions}} n_{\text{L23,tot}}$.
17. Return the final score $S$ as a single numerical value representing the overall agreement between model and observed age-abundance relations.
output_justification: Table 7 in Appendix D provides the quantitative scores. For the row 'Triple-system' DTD and the column 'Two-infall' SFH, the score listed under 'Age–[O/Fe]' is 1.281. This score represents the weighted average RMS difference in median ages between the model and APOGEE/L23 data across [O/Fe] bins and Galactic regions.
